title: Quarterback 101
subtitle: The Field General Who Runs Every Play

What you'll learn: Why QBs touch the ball on every play
The difference between pocket passers and scramblers

script.hook: The quarterback touches the ball on every single offensive play. But there's way more happening than just throwing passes. Let's break down football's most important position.

sections.title: The Play Starts Here
sections.content: Every offensive play begins with the QB receiving the snap from the center. From that moment, they have about 2-4 seconds to either hand the ball off, throw it, or scramble before the defense reaches them.
sections.onScreen: slow-motion snap sequence + '2-4 SECONDS TO DECIDE' timer

sections.title: Pre-Snap Reading
sections.content: Watch a QB before the play starts - they're scanning the defense, counting players, identifying potential blitzes. They might even change the entire play by calling an 'audible' if they see something the defense is showing.
sections.onScreen: QB eyes scanning defense + 'AUDIBLE!' callout graphic

sections.title: Decision Making Under Pressure
sections.content: Once the ball is snapped, QBs are reading the defense in real-time. Which receiver is getting open? Is the pocket collapsing? Should they throw it away to avoid a sack? Every decision happens in split seconds.
sections.onScreen: split-second decisions: throw/run/escape arrows + pressure clock

sections.title: Different Styles
sections.content: Some QBs are 'pocket passers' who stay protected and throw with precision. Others are 'dual-threat' QBs who can hurt you with their legs too. Both styles can be effective, just in different ways.
sections.onScreen: side-by-side: pocket passer vs scrambling QB highlights

sections.title: Quick Recap
sections.content: Remember: QBs are the field generals. They read, decide, and execute - all under pressure.

questions.question: Who touches the ball on every offensive play?
questions.explanation: The quarterback touches the ball on every single offensive play. They receive the snap from the center and then decide whether to throw, hand off, or run.

questions.question: What is an 'audible' in football?
options: When the QB throws a touchdown pass
When the QB changes the play at the line of scrimmage
When the QB calls a timeout
When the QB runs with the ball
questions.explanation: An audible is when the quarterback changes the play at the line of scrimmage based on what they see from the defense. Famous QBs shout code words like 'Omaha!' to signal the change.

questions.question: A quarterback sees the defense showing blitz before the snap. What's their best option?
options: Always run the play as called
Call an audible to change to a quicker passing play
Take a timeout to talk to the coach
Hand the ball off no matter what
questions.explanation: Good quarterbacks read the defense and adjust. If they see a blitz coming, calling an audible to a quick slant or screen pass can beat the pressure and potentially result in a big gain.

questions.question: What's the main difference between a 'pocket passer' and a 'dual-threat' quarterback?
options: Dual-threat QBs can both pass and run effectively
Pocket passers don't throw as far
Dual-threat QBs never stay in the pocket
questions.explanation: A dual-threat QB can hurt defenses with both their arm and legs - they can throw passes AND run for significant yards. Pocket passers stay protected and focus on precise passing.

keyTerms.definition: When the QB changes the play at the line of scrimmage based on what they see from the defense
The protected area behind the offensive line where the QB stands to throw
When extra defenders rush the quarterback beyond the normal pass rush
When the QB runs with the ball, usually to escape pressure
